avalancheActivity.comment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form on New Year's Eve especially in the regions exposed to precipitation. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The older wind slabs will be covered with new snow in some cases and therefore difficult to recognise.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind and new snow to low altitudes.

snowpackStructure.comment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Faceted weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

tendency.comment: Wind and new snow: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The avalanche prone locations are rather rare. These avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
avalancheActivity.highlights: In some localities wind and new snow: This applies especially along the border with France.

snowpackStructure.comment: Below approximately 2400 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. At higher altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

avalancheActivity.comment:
In these regions from a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
avalancheActivity.highlights: In all aspects a little snow is lying.

snowpackStructure.comment: Hardly any snow is lying at intermediate and high altitudes. The snowpack is stable and its surface has a resilient crust.

avalancheActivity.comment:
The weather conditions will cause a slight rise in the avalanche danger in the afternoon in the regions exposed to substantial precipitation. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and generally at elevated altitudes.
Even in moderately steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard crust.
avalancheActivity.highlights: Wind and new snow to intermediate altitudes.

snowpackStructure.comment:
The new snow will be deposited on a crust in all aspects. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

tendency.comment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.
